entry.title: Manual batch split in EWM outbound delivery app
entry.content:
Hello experts.

We have a very specific requirement related to outbound deliveries created from sales order. The business is using EWM for outbound processes.

  Once the delivery is created, the business needs to split the batches in the outbound delivery based on specific situations. They cannot have automatic batch determination. The problem here is, the app Manage Outbound Delivery  app does not give us that option.

I am able to add a batch to the line item:

But I don't see an option to split the line item into multiple batches. Is there any way we can achieve this in the system (using this app or any other app/process)?

Kindly let me know 

Thanks

Snigdhodeep

entry.title: HANA System Database copy scenario
entry.content:
Hello Team ,

Can you please help to clarify below .

Database Copy: System Database | SAP Help Portal

Scenario 2

System 1:

Host A: host_role = worker ,

Host B: host_role = xs_worker

System 2:

Host C: host_role = worker

Why recovery from System1 to System 2 is possible ? System 2 does not contain xs_worker role .This has been mentioned in above link which is confusing .

 

In the same link , result is contradicting for scenario 1 .

Scenario 1

System 1

Host A: host_role = worker

Host B: host_role = standby

System 2

Host C: host_role = worker, xs_worker

Host ðŸ˜§ host_role = standby, xs_standby

Recovery of system database from System 2 to System 1 is not possible which make sense because System 1 does not have xs_worker and xs_standby role .

 

Can anyone please help me to clarify why in Scenario 2 , recovery is possible from System 1 to System 2 although system2 is missing xs_worker role . ??

 

SAP HANA

entry.title: Streamline SAP Commerce Product Data: A Guide to the Catalog Optimization Agent in SAP CX AI Toolkit
entry.content:
Introduction

Managing a product catalog in an SAP Commerce Cloud system is often a battle against chaos. Product managers and merchandisers frequently encounter inconsistent product descriptions, missing attributes, and the challenging task of translating thousands of SKUs for global markets. A disorganized catalog doesn't just look bad, but it hurts searchability, lowers conversion rates, and creates massive manual workloads.

Enter the Catalog Optimization Agent, a powerful new capability within the SAP CX AI Toolkit. This agent is designed to act as your tireless digital assistant, automating the heavy lifting of catalog hygiene. Whether you need to generate missing product descriptions, standardize attributes, or translate content into multiple languages, this agent orchestrates the entire process using Generative AI.

In this blog, we will explore the core tools that power this agent, how to set it up, how to verify its output in the playground, and finally, how to review and publish the results using the Agent Insights dashboard.

What Problem Does It Solve?

Before we dive into the setup, let's look at the specific pain points this agent addresses:

  • Incomplete Data: Automatically fills in missing descriptions or technical attributes based on existing data or images.
  • Inconsistency: Ensures all product descriptions follow a specific brand voice and format.
  • Localization Bottlenecks: Instantly translates product data into target languages.
  • Manual Effort: Replaces hours of spreadsheet work with automated AI workflows.

Prerequisites

To get started with the Catalog Optimization Agent, ensure you have the following in place:

  1. Access to SAP CX AI Toolkit: You must have a valid license and user access.
  2. SAP Commerce Cloud Connection: Your SAP Commerce Cloud instance must be connected to the toolkit. This is where the agent will pull product data from.
  3. Permissions: Ensure your user role allows you to create and configure agents.

For detailed prerequisites and system requirements, refer to the official documentation.

Deep Dive: The Core Tools

The Catalog Optimization Agent isn't just one block of AI; it utilizes four specialized AI tools that work in sequence to refine your data. Understanding these tools is key to mastering the agent.

1. Analysis Tool

This is the decision maker and brain of the operation. The Analysis Tool evaluates the current state of a product record, checking what data is present and what is missing. Based on the selected source language and your custom instructions, it decides which downstream tools need to be triggered, essentially creating the "to-do list" for the other tools.

The tool determines whether the product's attributes and description are complete and consistent with each other. If they are, the agent will skip generation and move directly to translation (if configured). However, if the analysis identifies missing attributes, inadequate descriptions, or inconsistencies between them, the agent will generate fresh content using the appropriate tools. You can also set a minimum description word length to ensure adequate content coverage.

2. Attribute Generation Tool

If the Analysis Tool detects missing or incorrect product attributes in the source language, this tool kicks in. It gives you the flexibility to select from various available sources, such as documents, descriptions, and images, to consider for attribute generation. You can also choose whether to only create or modify the values of existing attributes, or to create new attributes that can be stored as classification attributes.

3. Description Generation Tool

This tool focuses on creative content, taking raw attributes and transforming them into detailed product descriptions. You can configure it with specific templates to control:

  • Tone: Professional, Witty, Luxury, etc.
  • Length: Short summaries for mobile or detailed features for product pages.

You can choose from pre-configured description templates or manually select the tone and length when using the default template. Custom instructions allow you to guide the generation process and highlight specific areas of focus. To learn more about product description templates, refer to the templates documentation.

4. Translation Tool

The final step in the chain is localization. Once the attributes and descriptions are finalized in the master language, this tool manages the translation into your target locales. It ensures that product data remains accurate while adapting the marketing nuance for local markets. The tool only considers localized attributes from your product content, as only these can be translated. 

To use this tool, your user must have the translation feature enabled for descriptions and/or attributes. This can be configured in the Organization Configuration settings as explained in our documentation.

Human-in-the-Loop Review: For each tool that creates or modifies data, there is an optional human-in-the-loop step that allows you to review the generated content before publishing it to your connected SAP Commerce Cloud system. This ensures you maintain full control over what gets published to your live catalog.

Visualizing the Workflow

To understand how these tools interact, visualize the product data flowing from your Commerce Cloud source.

Step-by-Step Guide: Setting Up the Agent

Setting up the agent is a straightforward process. Follow these steps to configure your own optimization assistant.

Step 1: Choose Agent Type

Navigate to AI Agents in the navigation bar of the SAP CX AI Toolkit interface. Click on Create AI Agent to begin a new configuration.

In the Agent Type step, select Catalog Optimization Agent from the available agent types.

Step 2: Agent Setup

In the Agent Setup step, you will be prompted to provide the core details for your agent:

  • Name: Give your agent a clear, descriptive name (e.g., "Global Catalog Optimizer").
  • Description: Add a description to help identify the agent's purpose.

Step 3: Agent Trigger

In this step, the Source Application and Entity are prefilled by default. You only need to specify the product catalog whose products the agent should process. Optionally, you can further refine when the agent is triggered by providing additional details such as categories, classification catalog, and its classification classes. This allows you to limit the agentâ€™s execution to a targeted subset of products.

Please note that the only trigger option currently supported is product creation. Agent triggers do not support product updates yet.

Step 4: Agent Settings

In the Agent Settings step, you'll configure how the agent behaves and which tools it uses:

  • Agent Instructions: Review and adapt the sample generation prompt to your specific needs. This is where you tell the agent how to behave using natural language.
  • Agent Tools: Define parameters for each of the four core tools described in the previous section. As already explained, each tool offers configuration options for generation language, data sources, description templates, translation languages, and publishing strategies.

Once you are satisfied with the configuration, click Save. The agent is now ready to be tested!

Step 5: Test in Playground

Before deploying your agent to a live workflow, it can be tested by following the steps below:

  1. Select a Product: Use the product search to find a product to test with. Note that the search works across your entire synced products, not just the products covered by the agent's trigger configuration.
  2. Run the Agent: Click the Generate button to execute the agent.
  3. Review the Results: Review the output, including the logs, to see the results from all tools. You'll also find a link to the Agent Insights page for further review.
  4. Refine: If the output isn't perfect, go back and tweak your instructions or tool configurations.

Agent Insights

Once your agent has processed a batch of products, the Agent Insights dashboard becomes your command center. This is where human oversight meets AI automation. You don't have to blindly trust the AI; you can optionally review, edit, and approve every change before it hits your live catalog. It is accessible through the playground as well as Smart Actions on the homepage.

The Dashboard Overview

The Insights page lists all products the agent has processed. On the left, you can filter by product catalog or time range (e.g., "Last 7 days") to find specific updates.

Reviewing Descriptions

Clicking on a product opens the Product Description tab. Here, you can see the AI-generated descriptions for every supported language.

  • Edit: If the phrasing isn't quite right, click the pencil icon to manually tweak the text.
  • Publish: If it looks good, hit the Publish button to send it directly to SAP Commerce Cloud.

Managing Attributes

The Product Attributes and Classification Attributes tabs allow you to audit the attributes data.

  • Side-by-Side Comparison: The view clearly shows the Current Value (what's in your system now) vs. the Generated Value (what the LLM suggests).
  • Select & Approve: You can check the boxes for the specific attributes you want to keep and ignore or delete the rest.
  • Publish: When you click Publish, you can choose to Overwrite existing data or Append to it, ensuring you don't accidentally wipe out manual work.

Creating New Attributes

If the agent discovers a feature that doesn't exist in your catalog schema yet, you can create that new attribute class directly from this screen using the Create New Attribute workflow.

Conclusion

The Catalog Optimization Agent is a game-changer for merchandisers. By combining the structured decision-making of the Analysis Tool with the creative power of GenAI, you can ensure your storefront is always fresh, accurate, and ready for global customers.

Give it a try today and let AI handle the spreadsheet work!

Further Reading & Documentation

  • SAP CX AI Toolkit - Main Page
  • (Beta) Create a Catalog Optimization Agent | SAP Help Portal

We hope you enjoyed reading this blog! We'd love to hear from you. Feel free to reach out with any feedback on the product or suggestions for new features. Your insights help us continue to improve and innovate.

Thanks,
Gaurav Kamboj (gaurav.kamboj@sap.com) & Shubham Gupta (shubham.gupta03@sap.com)
CX AI Toolkit Development Team

P.S. We practice what we preach! In the spirit of efficiency and GenAI, elements of this blog were drafted with the help of the very tools we build. After all, why should our users have all the fun? ðŸ˜‰

Dear Customer,

Have you recently requested provisioning of SAP Cloud ALM? We are thrilled to welcome you aboard! Your journey with #SAP Cloud ALM is about to begin, and weâ€™re here to ensure it is smooth and efficient.

To assist you in this journey, we would like to invite you to one of the below online webinars where weâ€™ll guide you through the setup process and answer any questions you may have.

What to Expect in the Webinar

  • Provide guidance on the next steps to use the solution effectively.
  • Highlight essential training resources to support you and your teamâ€™s learning journey.

To make the most of your SAP Cloud ALM onboarding experience, hereâ€™s what you need to do:

Weâ€™re excited to embark on this journey with you! Letâ€™s make the most of SAP Cloud ALM together. See you at the webinar!

entry.title: Re: SAP Cloud Integration - Upgrade Readiness Design Guidelines/Best Practices for Future Readiness
entry.content:
Hi @kamlesh_zanje ,

Would like to check if there is any similar library provided by SAP on building the batchset raw input? The ODATA Adapter seem having limitation not able to handle all the scenarios and raised an incident with SAP, that advised to use HTTP adapter instead, that lead to us need to build the raw batchset content.

Currently I am using library below where it is working fine for us in lower version, but not the Groovy step 2.x version. 

The libraries that using:

import org.apache.commons.io.IOUtils;
import org.apache.olingo.odata2.api.client.batch.BatchChangeSet;
import org.apache.olingo.odata2.api.client.batch.BatchChangeSetPart;
import org.apache.olingo.odata2.api.client.batch.BatchPart;
import org.apache.olingo.odata2.api.ep.EntityProvider;
import org.apache.olingo.odata2.api.client.batch.BatchSingleResponse

 

Alternatively, we can download the library(jar file, pretty small less than 2mb) and import into the iFlow, not sure what will be the impact in future. 

Thanks and appreciate your response on this.

entry.title: Fiscal Year Variant Change from 4-4-5 to Calendar Year
entry.content:
Many companies in retail use the 4â€‘4â€‘5 fiscal calendar for their financial closing. But sometimes the business decides to move to a calendar year (K4) instead. Changing the fiscal year variant in SAP sounds simple, but it comes with important restrictions and risks.

Why SAP Blocks the Change

SAP puts a hard stop error when you try to change the fiscal year variant if any transactions already exist in the company code. This is because changing the fiscal year structure after postings have happened can create serious issues, such as:

  • Data inconsistency in financial postings

  • Wrong period determination for documents

  • Open items not matching correctly

  • Reporting mismatches across modules

  • Integration failures with connected systems

  • System performance issues during period close

  • Historical data becoming confusing or incorrect

Because of these risks, SAP does not recommend changing the fiscal year variant directly in a live system.

Possible Solutions

There are three ways to handle this situation:

Option 1: Contact SAP Consulting

SAPâ€™s expert team can analyze your system and suggest the safest approach. This is the most controlled option but may take time and cost money.

Option 2: Shorten the Current Fiscal Year

You can â€œshort endâ€ the current fiscal year, create a new fiscal year variant based on the calendar year, and assign it to the company code. This approach is more complex and may not fit all business scenarios.

Option 3: Change the Variant from 4â€‘4â€‘5 to K4 and Test Endâ€‘toâ€‘End

This is the most practical option for this scenario. You change the fiscal year variant directly and then perform full testing to ensure nothing breaks.

We will proceed with Option 3.

How to Change the Fiscal Year Variant

  1. Go to OB37 and try to change the fiscal year variant assignment.

     

     

  2. You will see this error message: â€œCheck if postings already exist in Co.Code XXXX / Ledger 0L!â€

     

     

    This is SAPâ€™s hard stop.

  3. To continue, convert this error into a warning:

    • SPRO â†’ Financial Accounting â†’ Financial Accounting Global Settings â†’ Tools â†’ Change Message Control

    • Application Area: FINS_ACDOC_CUST

    • Message Number: 116

    • Change it from Error to Warning

    •  

       

  4. After this change, SAP will allow you to update the fiscal year variant.

    Important Reminder

    Changing the fiscal year variant is a highâ€‘risk activity. Before and after the change, make sure to:

    • Test all endâ€‘toâ€‘end business processes

    • Validate all integrations (especially external systems)

    • Check for any data inconsistencies

    • Confirm that reporting works correctly

    • Ensure no postings behave differently

    Only move forward once everything is fully tested and approved.

entry.title: Re: Creation of reporting entity for stutory report
entry.content:
1.Open APP â€œImplementation Activitiesâ€ in S4Hana Cloud system.

2. Select item Compliance and Trade -> Legal Compliance -> Compliance Reporting -> Statutory Reporting.

3.Exectue activity Setting Up Your Statutory Reporting.

4.Click on Edit button.

5.You can choose to create new entries or copy current exist reporting entity by clicking on those two different buttons.

entry.title: Re: Automating China VAT Invoice Process
entry.content:
Hello @ztee ,

just saw your comment, thanks for reaching out. 

Regarding the first question, 'receiveInvoice' is more like a business action. It means that the invoice has been received from the vendor and is then ready to be signed off by accountant. 

About the second question, for now, in our OData API, 'declareInvoice' will set the invoice declared if the invoice meets the prerequisites in the source system. In our solution, if you use our Fiori apps, then this will be declared to the Golden Tax System after some configurations(direct connection enablement) are properly set. 

It seems you are interested in our China Incoming VAT Invoice solution, welcome to contact if you have any further questions.

BR,

George

entry.title: Journal Entry Post Synchronous API: How to identify which line item caused an error when using API?
entry.content:
Hello there,
I am encountering an issue when posting data via an SAP API.
â€»I'm using S/4HANA Cloud, Journal Entry-Post Synchronous API

When an error occurs during API execution, I can confirm that an error has occurred, but I cannot identify which line item caused the error. The error message returned by the API does not contain line-item-level details.

On the other hand, when I execute the same process without using API (for example, via the standard SAP app or UI), the system displays the line items, so I can easily identify where the error occurred.

Because of this difference, troubleshooting is difficult when using the API.

I would like to ask the following questions:

ãƒ»Is there any way to retrieve line-item-level error detail as part of the API response?
ãƒ»Is there any recommended method to identify which item caused the error when using API?
ãƒ»If this is a known limitation, what are the typical workarounds used in SAP projects?

Any guidance or best practice would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance.

entry.title: Re: Understanding GOS Attachments and Their Backend Tables in SAP ABAP
entry.content:
Great article, Juveria â€” this is one of the clearest summaries of the GOS attachment architecture Iâ€™ve seen.

I would just add one important practical layer from real projects:
in many S/4HANA systems, attachments are no longer stored in SAPoffice tables (SOOD/SOFM) but in Content Server or ArchiveLink, with only the relationship stored in SRGBTBREL and TOA tables* (like TOA01, TOA02).

So for audits, migrations, or mass download scenarios, the full chain usually becomes:
SRGBTBREL â†’ BOR object â†’ ArchiveLink (TOA) â†’ Content Server*.

This is especially critical during S/4HANA conversions and system carveâ€‘outs, where teams often migrate the business objects but forget to validate whether the linked content repository is still accessible â€” leading to â€œemptyâ€ attachments even though SRGBTBREL entries still exist.

Your breakdown makes it much easier for teams to design reliable attachment audits and migration checks. Thanks for sharing this â€” very valuable for both ABAP and functional consultants ðŸ‘

entry.title: Re: is SAP BODS capable to write to Microsoft Fabric Ware...

@halickiandrzej94  -  To upgrade the groovy script flow step version from 1.x to 2.x, please open the groovy script in its corresponding editor and leverage the upgrade action. Here you would upgrade to the major version of the groovy flow step.

The information message that you have highighted is the result of the update action which is applicable for the minor version change, for an e.g 1.x to 1.y.  The component update feature is available for all the flow steps, adapters but for the minor version update, not for the major version upgrade Please refer this blog post the component update feature https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-integration-suite-update-version-of-an-integration-flow-component/ba-p/14158284

Let me know if you have still doubt.

entry.title: Re: Can FBD1 be used for AP posting?
entry.content:
For information, FBD1 is used to create recurring entry documents. It is designed for general ledger postings (e.g., accruals, depreciation, recurring expenses). The recurring entry template is later picked up by F.14 (Program for recurring entries) to generate actual FI documents.

Why your batch input fails because, you are trying to post PK 31 (vendor) and PK 50 (expense). Vendor line items (AP subledger postings) are not supported in FBD1 recurring entry templates. That is why the amount and G/L account fields are missing in the batch input recording â€” the AP line item simply isnâ€™t captured by FBD1â€™s dynpro flow. FBD1 only records G/L accounts, not vendor/customer subledger accounts.

If you want recurring postings involving vendors (AP), use F-02 (general posting) or FB01 for one-time manual postings. For recurring vendor invoices, you should use Recurring Vendor Invoices functionality in MM (Logistics Invoice Verification) or Accounts Payable module. Alternatively, you can set up parked documents or payment requests depending on your business process.

entry.title: Tools in Service Transactions
entry.content:
You are a service manager

  • You create a service order to plan a service on customer site. 
  • You identify that this certain service can only be carried out using a specific tool such as a lifting platform.
  • You are wondering how you can use such tools in your service order.

Solution

  • In this blog I am going to explain how you can enable products as tools that can be used in service transactions.

 

Configurations in Customizing

Configurations are to be done that are are prerequisites for creation of products as tools.

Change Material Type FHMI

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Basic Settings -> Material Types -> Define Attributes of Material Types. 
  • You flag the checkbox for material type FHMI with description Production Resource/Tool and open the details.
  • You flag the checkbox Sales in the box User departments. (See screenshot in Figure 1.)  

Figure 1: Change view â€œMaterial typesâ€ for material type FHMI (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Change Screen Sequences

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Configuring the Material Master -> Define Structure of Data Screens for Each Screen Sequence.
  • In displayed view you select the checkbox for screen sequence 21 with description Std ind.(short) tab pages and double-click on Data screens on the left panel.
  • In displayed view you select the checkbox for screen sequence 21 and screen 17, then you double-click on Subscreens on the left panel.
  • In displayed view you change the program of screen sequence 21, screen 17, and subscreen 4 from SAPLMGD1 to SAPLCRMS4_PRUDUCT_SUBSCREEN. (See screenshot in Figure 2.)  

Figure 2: View Subscreens (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Maintain status for MARA-SRV_DURA and MARA-SRV_DURA_UOM

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
  • In displayed view search for field name MARA-SRV_DURA and double-click on this line so the view Field Groups is opened. In this view change the maintenance status from V to VF. (See screenshot in Figure 3.) 
  • You do the same for field name MARA-SRV_DURA_UOM.

Figure 3: View Field Groups for field name MARA-SRV_DURA (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Hide MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI for material type FHMI

Since the fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI are not relevant for tools used in service transactions, you can hide them for the field reference that is assigned to the material type FHMI.

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
  • You choose a new field selection group for the two fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL (Response Profile) and MARA-SRV_SERWI (Service Profile) for instance you enter 211 as new selection group. 
  • You click on button Field Selection Maintenance at the end of the line so that the field selection group 211 is displayed.
  • Since these two fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI are not relevant for tool items, you can hide them for the field reference that is assigned to the material type FHMI. For instance, you can set the radio button for Hide for field reference HALB that is assigned to the material type FHMI. (See screenshot in Figure 4.)

Figure 4: Example for hiding fields in selection group 211 (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Create a Product for Tools

  • You create a new product for material type FHMI (Production Resource/Tool), for instance SRV_TOOL (Service Tool) for industry sector M (Mechanical engineering).
  • As the configurations are done in customizing, you can maintain data in view Sales: sales org. 2 such as sales organization for instance 1710, distribution channel for instance 10, and item category group SRVT (Service Tool)
  • You can check view Prod.resouces/tools and maintain the work duration for this product.

Figure 5: Product Master view Prod.resources/tools of example product SRV_TOOL (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Controlling Integration

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Integration with Other SAP Components -> Customer Relationship Management -> Settings for Service Processing -> Controlling Integration -> Determine Cost Center and Activity Type for Tool.
  • You assign a cost center and an activity type to the created product SRV_TOOL. (See screenshot in Figure 6.)
  • As for service products, you maintain cost rates for respective cost center and activity type in SAP GUI transaction KP26 or open the following path in SAP Menu: Accounting -> Controlling -> Cost Center Accounting -> Planning ->Activity Output/Prices -> Change.

Figure 6: Example of cost center and activity type assignment to product SRV_TOOL (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Tool Items in Service Transactions

Now letâ€™s process a tool item in service transactions. You can create a service quotation for a service and a tool that is required for execution of the service. (See screenshot in Figure 7.) 

Figure 7: Example of a service quotation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

The duration for the tool item is derived from product master data, in this example two hours. (See screenshot in Figure 8.) 

Figure 8: Example of a duration of a service quotation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

After accepting, a service order is created as follow-up. Of course, you can create a service order for a service and a tool directly. (See screenshot in Figure 9.) 

Figure 9: Example of a service order tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You enter the actual duration that is used for the tool. In this example three hours, see screenshot in Figure 10.

Figure 10: Example of a service confirmation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You complete the service confirmation. For the service confirmation tool item, a controlling document is created to post actual cost. (See screenshot in Figure 11.) 

Figure 11: Example of a service confirmation (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

The actual duration was passed on as quantity to post the actual cost. You can check the quantity in app Service Actuals when item-based accounting is used. (See screenshot in Figure 12.) 

Figure 12: Service Actuals for a tool item when item-based accounting is used (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Conclusion

Hopefully after reading this blog post, you will have more in-depth knowledge about the enablement of tools and its process in service transactions.

Please donâ€™t hesitate to raise your questions in Q&A forum of SAP Community or leave your comments below!

For more details, please visit the full product assistance documentation in the SAP Help Portal:

  • Items in Service Orders | SAP Help Portal 
  • Tool Items in Service Transactions | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: What is the most efficient way to create a search string which always hits (only once) in TPAMA?
entry.content:
Hello SAPers,

many times we need in T028P to define a deviating rule from T028G which is independent of the text string (FEBRE table).

So far we are using (^| |?)($|?) but this leads to absurd number of hits and loops within BSPS_PATTERN_SEARCH, which we believe hinders performance with banks statement import.

How have you approached such requirement?

We think that maybe (^)($|?) could do it, but we are unsure as in the simulation it doesn't get any results, but in FEB_BSPROC it seems to work.

Any ideas?

I cannot simply delete the search string in TPAMA, as then it saves the T028P inexistent search strings as inactive.

entry.title: Re: Styling your Custom Frontend like SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2
entry.content:
Hi @StKollos ,

thanks! That is a very good point and I thought to add it to this post but it could probably be a post for itself ðŸ˜› 

We are in those discussions internally but it takes a bit more to officially release such library. You need to dedicate quite some resources to manage an official maintenance and deprecation process. This would limit our internal developments and also for sure bind more resources to this topic permanently. Also we would get less flexible to make breaking changes as we have no control who uses them.

I "believe" in time we might see such a release but I cannot say when. So you can use them but you cannot complain if something needs to be adapted if we change something.

Also from my experience, when you really have a very custom requirement of a customer, it often is better to style the application but have unlimited freedom how you "design" the features and elements to have the biggest impact on the user experience. For this, the CSS is a very good approach. If you need a 100% table style UI, you can use the "custom services". But for sure, there are cool elements like the next best action buttons, the timeline and some more that are just great looking ready components. ðŸ™‚

Note: I am not part of the product organizations and have no direct insights, all the above is more or less my common sense / general knowledge regarding making the libary public. ðŸ™‚

Appreciating your thoughts!

Thanks

Jens

entry.title: Settlement Error in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Cost Element Not Assigned to Source Structure
entry.content:
Settlement Error in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Cost Element Not Assigned to Source Structure

**Body:**

Hello SAP Community,

I'm encountering an error when settling an investment project (F4568) in **SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition**.

**Error Message:**
```
No source assignment found for cost element 61003000

Diagnosis:
The sender bears the YS source structure and was debited with costs from the 61003000 cost element. This cost element is not assigned to any source assignment in the A000 controlling area of the YS source structure.

Procedure:
Maintain the YS source structure.
```

**Environment:**
- SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
- Controlling Area: A000
- Cost Element: 61003000 (Primary cost element, Category 1 - Travel Expense Hotel)
- Project Type: Investment Project (AUC)
- Transaction: Settlement (F4568)

**What I've Found:**
1. In "Analysis of Value Category Assignments" app, cost element 61003000 appears in the "Not assigned" list
2. I tried to assign it to a Value Category but cannot edit from this screen
3. Allocation Structure YT (PS Project Settlement) uses Cost Element Group "100_CE" which doesn't exist in the system

**My Question:**
Could someone provide a **step-by-step solution** with specific **app names and IDs** to resolve this error in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?

Please note: I need solutions specific to **Public Cloud only** - on-premise transaction codes (like OKEU, KAH2) are not applicable.

Thank you in advance for your help!

entry.title: Re: Order to Cash Process
entry.content:
Yes quite possible. Follow the below steps

1. Sales Order Creation
Sales order is created in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Sales. Shipping condition â€œTM â€“ Int. Planningâ€ triggers Transportation Management (TM) integration for freight planning and execution.

2. Outbound Delivery
Delivery document is generated from the sales order. TM provides freight units and planning results. Delivery is released for warehouse processing.

3. Post Goods Issue (PGI)
At PGI, inventory is credited and Goods-In-Transit (GIT) is debited. This ensures stock is removed from inventory but not yet recognized as COGS until POD confirmation.

4. Proof of Delivery (POD)
POD functionality is available in Advanced ATP / Logistics Execution. Once POD is confirmed, the system triggers GIT â†’ COGS accounting:

  • Credit GIT
  • Debit COGS

5. Billing & Revenue Recognition
Billing document is created in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Billing.

Accounting entries:

  • Debit Trade Receivables
  • Credit Revenue

Event-Based Revenue Recognition (EBRR) ensures revenue is recognized only after POD.

entry.title: Change request not created on API ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest_In
entry.content:
Dear All

In view of our development task,  we are using SOAP API ProductMDMBulkReplicateRequest_In to get the material data from external system(non SAP).

First BC set MDGM_MDG_MATERIAL_CR_SOAP_09 activated and CR types MATL0I , MATL0U created, also decision tables configured.   Next SOAMANAGER and DRFIMG configured. 

Then executed sample payload and able to update the material fields and can see the ProductMDMBulkReplicateConfirmation_Out XML in SXI_MONITOR but   change request not created.

 

Debugged the API and see that go_mdg_mm_2_sta not bound, seems this is the reason for CR not created.

 

Am i missing anything here?  If so , could some one provide your inputs please.

 

regards

Chandra Kishore.

entry.title: How to Configure South Korea Tax Box Structure VAT01 for Form and File Changes
entry.content:
ä¸€. Background and Symptom

The form and files have changed in the General Taxpayer VAT Declaration report for South Korea.

The General Taxpayer VAT Declaration report enables you to generate your General Taxpayer VAT Declaration and fulfill the statutory reporting requirements in South Korea. You generate this report in the Run Statutory Reports app.

The following tax box definitions need to be updated:

  1. Adjust the following tax box numbers:

Old Tax Box Number

New Tax Box Number

Description

10-1

11

Import Payment Incentives of Export Company

20-1

22

VAT-Exempt Amount for Small Personal Business

        2. Create a new tax box as follows:

Tax Box Number

Description

25

Interim Assessment Tax Amount

äºŒ. Prerequisites

This SAP KBA is relevant only for South Korea. Ensure that you have the necessary authorizations as delivered with the Configuration Expert - Business Process Configuration (SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT) business role template.

ä¸‰. Solution

You can change the tax box structure definition via the configuration activity Define Enhanced Tax Box Structure (ID 103011). Follow the steps below to modify, delete, and add the required tax groups and tax boxes.

Steps:

  1. Open the configuration activity Define Enhanced Tax Box Structure (ID 103011).
  • In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the activity.
    If you are using the Manage Your Solution app, select the activity under Finance > Statutory Reporting > Tax.
    If you are using the CBC system, select the activity under Accounting > Tax Management > Tax Declaration > Tax Declaration.

        2. Open the coSelect the target country/region.

  • Select â€œSouth Koreaâ€ as the target country/region.

        3. Copy the tax box structure to a new version.
             To make changes, you must copy the tax box structure as a new version. This ensures that all changes are done in the new                        version of the tax box structure.

  • Select the current tax box structure, and click Copy As.

  • Specify a new Valid From date. Note that the Valid From date should not be the same as other Valid From dates under the same tax box structure type (TaxBoxStTy).

  • Click Copy or press Enter. And press Enter again if a warning message appears.

  • Click Copy All to copy the existing record to this new tax box structure version.

  • Click Save after you copied it. A new record will be displayed under VAT01.

        4. Delete tax boxes.

  • In the new version of the tax box structure, select the Define Tax Boxes (External) tab.
  • Select the following tax boxes:

Tax Box Number

Description

Comments

entry.title: Extreme performance problems with new application for Crystal Reports in .Net
entry.content:
Hello there. I'm currently in the process of rebuilding the old print handling of my companies Delphi application. We used to use the native Delphi components from Crystal Reports for it but eventually they stopped working reliably, so i built it new. Printing is now done via a C# application that gets triggered with a .json file and then does the whole printing using the CR SDK.

Now the application is complete, after some confusing hacks to get it to work how we wanted it, and has been rolled out to the first few customers and we are experiencing extreme delays in performance. We are speaking of up to 30 seconds between pressing the print button in our Delphi program and the Preview opening, as well as printjobs without a preview taking up to 10 seconds to be printed.

This seems to vary heavily, but even on my developer machine it takes up to 6-7 seconds to get to the preview. Compared to the previous almost instantaneous process with the native components this is an unacceptable delay. I have been tracking down the performance loss, especially with the customers who experienced up to 30 seconds and more, and found out two very specific sources for the delay.

1: The setting of a printers name in the property ReportDocument.PrintOptions.Printername (Up to 5 Seconds and more)

2: The method ReportDocument.PrintOptions.CopyFrom(), after we modified the PrintOptions. (Up to 20 seconds and more!)

I have googled, read forum posts, compared documentation and tried out a lot of things, but nothing helped. I can barely find anything about this problem at all, which i find insane. Such a huge loss in performance surely must have been noticed by almost anyone using the SDK?

I don't know if i did something wrong in using the SDK, but im basically out of options, so i hope someone here can help me. I'd be happy to supply further information as well as source code if needed

entry.title: Re: Request to Create Separate Intercompany GL Accounts a...
entry.content:
You want to split intercompany postings into separate GL accounts by category:

  • Overheads / Common Costs
  • Rent
  • Trade
  • Expenses on Behalf Of
  • Fund Transfers

This is feasible but requires careful configuration because OBYA only allows one account pair per company code relationship. To achieve multiple accounts, you need additional logic.

Required SAP Configuration Changes

1. Create New GL Accounts
Define separate GL accounts under the intercompany reconciliation group. Ensure each account is marked as reconciliation account type â€œIntercompanyâ€ and allows automatic clearing.

2. Define Substitution Rules
In Public Cloud, you cannot freely enhance OBYA like in on-premise. Instead, you use Business Rules Framework (BRF+) / SSCUI substitutions to redirect postings to the correct intercompany GL based on:

  • Transaction type
  • Document type
  • Posting key
  • Cost center / account assignment

Example:

If document type = â€œFund Transferâ€ â†’ Post to Fund Transfer GL.

If allocation cycle posting â†’ Post to Overheads GL.

3. Transaction Tagging
Use Document Type or Posting Key to differentiate transaction categories. Alternatively, configure custom fields (via In-App extensibility) and map them in substitution rules.

4. Automatic Clearing
Ensure each intercompany GL account is flagged for automatic clearing in account master data. Define clearing rules (e.g., by company code, document type) so balances reconcile automatically.

5. Reporting
With separate GLs, you can now run Fiori apps (Intercompany Reconciliation, Balance Sheet, Trial Balance) to see balances by category. This improves visibility and makes reconciliation easier.

entry.title: Re: BTP ABAP SaaS Solution: Custom Field not available in...
entry.content:
Hi Johannes, 

there are two prerequisites for the predefined fields being available in the services.

  1. there needs to be a C-View which is exposed in a service using service definition/service binding
  2. this C-View needs to be also added to the predefined fields enabling object as related view entity (the related view entities array is basically the list of cds views to which the predefined fields are added as view extension when the predefined field enabling is activated)

In your case the predefined fields are only added to the I-View (which I guess is your RAP BO View) as you can see in the predefined fields enabling. So if you also have a service built with service definition/service binding, the exposed CDS View needs to be added, to the PCF enabling file, e.g.

{ 
"viewEntity":"/TCON/C_EMPLOYEE",
"baseObjectAlias":"EMPLOYEE",
"viewExtension":"/TCON/C_EMPLOYEE_EXT"
}

After activation of the enabling, also the extension of the C-view is generated and the fields are available in the services later on.

Hope, this helps and clarifies how predefined fields need to be configured.

Best Regards,
Daniel
